1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/d4387ae/2147483647/strip/true/crop/5704x3201+0+301/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F3f%2Fc6%2F4664b4c24623881bfda3e2c8fe98%2Fap26060537702769.jpg 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/1545048/2147483647/strip/true/crop/5704x3201+0+301/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F3f%2Fc6%2F4664b4c24623881bfda3e2c8fe98%2Fap26060537702769.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>A black plume of smoke rises from a warehouse at the industrial area of Sharjah City in the United Arab Emirates following reports of Iranian strikes in Dubai, United Arab Emirates Sunday.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Altaf Qadri/AP</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>The new war seems doubly troubling when you look at our own besieged democracy.</p><p>"It's domestic politics," said Timothy Snyder, whose books such as "On Tyranny" explore the rise of repressive regimes and how we risk becoming one of them. "The need to create some kind of foreign conflict so Trump can say we have to do special things around the elections. I honestly think its as simple as that."</p><p>Alas, World War I has lessons here, too — the government cracked down on dissidents, jailing pacifists, deporting foreign nationals who dared oppose the bloodshed.</p><p>War is a gamble. When you win big early on — kidnapping Maduro, killing Khamenei — you can fall under the spell of imagining it's a game you can win.</p><p>It could be argued that to start a war is to lose it. That's the sense you get, standing before any war memorial. Though now might not be the time to go to Washington — I know people who were afraid to step foot in Chicago Sunday, worried about blundering into some ad hoc Iranian counterstrike.</p><p>But if you do go to D.C., definitely visit the memorial to Vietnam, that bloody bog that took years to extricate ourselves from. And do seek out the World War I Memorial. The 58-foot wide sculpture is a true masterpiece, including a bit of the glory that some still itch to attach to war.</p><p>Here is how the National Park Service web site puts it: "At the center our hero calls his comrades into battle, illustrating the famous American battle cry from Belleau Wood: 'Come on, you sons of bitches, do you want to live forever?'"</p>
entries.author: Neil Steinberg

entries.title: Michael O'Brien's Super 25 high school basketball rankings for March 1, 2026
entries.summary: <p>The basketball season has a rhythm and flow. Teams play well for a week or two and then may struggle for a few games before finding their feet again. </p><p>There is no time for that in the one-and-done playoffs. A team can find itself buried with the season basically over after several bad minutes. </p><p>Lockport's players all referenced intensity after the Porters demolished Joliet West in what was supposed to be a very competitive Class 4A regional final on Friday. </p><p>"If we come out with intensity nobody can stop us," Lockport senior point guard Nathan Munson said. "[Against Joliet West] we came out with that. You saw the results."</p><p>Lockport joins the rankings at No. 21 after the victory. The Porters were ranked a few weeks ago but fell out after losing at Sandburg. Junior twins Nedas and Nojus Venckus lead the team, which is expected to be a Super 25 regular next season. </p><p>Lockport coach Dave Wilson had heavy praise for the twins on Friday.</p><p>"When your best players work their tails off every day it is contagious," Wilson said. "The twins work so hard in everything that the other teammates have no choice. When your leaders buy into intensity and they don’t take plays off, they don’t take practices off, they don’t take drills off, then the other 14 sure as heck don’t have an excuse."</p><p>The Porters move on to the Joliet West Sectional, where they will be underdogs against No. 11 Marist. </p><p><b>Simeon's big week</b></p><p>Simeon was actually No. 10 in the preseason Super 25 back in November. That was partly due to some confusion over the roster. Coach Tim Flowers didn't have a star, but returned a very experienced core. </p><p>The Wolverines' season hit a skid at the Pekin Holiday Tournament in late December with consecutive losses to Springfield, Morton and Crane. Simeon lost by 10 points to Lincoln Park in the city tournament and didn't advance to the final four. </p><p>But the Wolverines earned their way back into the Super 25 this week with impressive wins against Riverside-Brookfield and Young. </p><p>Simeon will face No. 14 St. Ignatius in the Class 4A Mount Carmel Sectional semifinals on Wednesday. </p><p><b>Super 25 updates</b></p><p>There were several close, competitive regional finals but very few upsets. The top half of the Super 25 remained largely unchanged, with only New Trier's win against St. Patrick shaking things up a bit. </p><p>Hersey and St. Laurence rejoined the rankings along with Lockport and Simeon. </p><p>Brother Rice makes its season debut. The Crusaders have been solid since November and played several good teams tight in losses, picking up single-digit defeats against Mount Carmel, Marist, Loyola and Neuqua Valley. </p><p>They will face No. 7 Homewood-Flossmoor in the Joliet West Sectional on Tuesday.</p><p><b>Super 25 high school basketball rankings for March 1, 2026</b><br>With record and last week's ranking</p><p><b>1. Benet (32-1) 1</b><br>Yorkville is next</p><p><b>2. DePaul Prep (29-3) 2</b><br>Handled Maine East</p><p><b>3. Curie (28-1) 3</b><br>Demolished Lyons</p><p><b>4. entries.title: Several people injured in multi-car crash in North Center
entries.summary: <p>Six people were injured, three critically, in a multi-car crash early Sunday in the North Center neighborhood, Chicago police said.</p><p>Three cars were involved in the crash around 3:20 a.m. in the 2300 block of West Addison Street.</p><p>The driver of the first car, a black Honda sedan, was speeding east on Addison Street when he ran a red light, according to police. The Honda struck a white Toyota SUV, which was facing south on Western Avenue.</p><p>The impact caused the Toyota to flip upside down and crash into a light pole, police said. The Honda lost control and struck a black Toyota sedan facing north on Western Avenue.</p><p>All three occupants of the Honda sedan were taken to area hospitals in critical condition, according to police. The driver, a 21-year-old man, was taken to Advocate Illinois Masonic Medical Center suffering from a head injury. An adult female passenger was taken to Northwestern Memorial Hospital with head and internal injuries. A 33-year-old male passenger was taken to Illinois Masonic with head and arm injuries.</p><p>The driver and passenger in the Toyota SUV were in fair condition at area hospitals, police said. The driver, a 57-year-old man, was taken to Illinois Masonic with head lacerations and chest bruises. The passenger, a 37-year-old man, was at Northwestern suffering from head lacerations.</p><p>The driver of the Toyota sedan, a 41-year-old woman, was in good condition at Endeavor Health Swedish Hospital, according to police.</p><p>Citations are pending as police investigate the crash.</p>
entries.author: Sun-Times Wire

entries.title: More early voting sites open Monday in Chicago, suburbs
entries.summary: <p>More early voting sites open Monday in Chicago and Cook County suburbs.</p><p>The <a class="Link" href="https://chicagoelections.gov/voting/early-voting" target="_blank" >50 ward early voting sites</a> in Chicago open as well as <a class="Link" href="https://www.cookcountyclerkil.gov/elections/ways-to-vote/early-voting/early-voting-locations" target="_blank" >55 sites in suburban Cook County</a>. Chicago voters have already been able to vote early, ahead of Election Day on March 17, at the Chicago Board of Elections office at 69 W. Washington St. and the downtown supersite at 137 S. State St. </p><p>More early voting sites in the collar counties also open Monday. <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/elections/2026/how-to-vote-illinois-primary" target="_blank" >Find a full list here</a>.</p><p>Voters who want to vote by mail can still sign up for a mail-in ballot. The deadline to apply is 5 p.m. March 12.</p><p>As of Saturday night, 3,165 early vote ballots have been cast in Chicago and 24,612 vote-by-mail ballots have been received, according to the Chicago Board of Elections.</p><div class="RelatedList Enhancement" data-module data-align-center> <div class="RelatedList-title">Related</div> <ul class="RelatedList-items"> <li class="RelatedList-items-item"> <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/elections/2026/how-to-vote-illinois-primary" target="_blank" >How to cast your ballot in the March 2026 Illinois primary</a> </li> </ul> </div> <p></p>

entries.title: Review: Outlaw country artist Margo Price pulls no punches in 90-minute showdown at Metro
entries.summary: <p>Margo Price is a little bit country, a little bit rock ‘n’ roll, and has a whole lot of “I don’t care what you think about it” attitude.</p><p>Her message was clear even before she and her four-piece band broke into a cover of George Jones’ “I Just Don’t Give A Damn” at the Metro in Wrigleyville Saturday night. And it was reinforced on another smoking cover of Blaze Foley’s “Oval Room.” Originally written in the ’80s about Ronald Reagan, the song “feels fitting right now,” Price said, singing her heart out on the lyrics, “he’s the president, but I don’t care!” and flipping both her birds as the sold-out crowd roared in approval.</p><p>This is the bold, loudmouth “Hard Headed Woman” everyone paid to see — and got their money’s worth in a 90-minute showdown that was as much honky-tonk as it was straight shooting from the hip about current issues often snuffed out of modern mainstream country music.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-f10000" name="image-f10000"></a> <picture " srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/e5be35f/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6122x3436+0+324/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F8f%2F36%2F1fbb24f54069852ead09fd3fabdb%2Fmargoprice-260302-07.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/1a3d724/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6122x3436+0+324/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F8f%2F36%2F1fbb24f54069852ead09fd3fabdb%2Fmargoprice-260302-07.jpg 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/e5be35f/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6122x3436+0+324/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F8f%2F36%2F1fbb24f54069852ead09fd3fabdb%2Fmargoprice-260302-07.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Margo Price performs Saturday at Metro in Wrigleyville. The singer’s 90-minute set featured a handful of originals from her twice-Grammy nominated 2025 album, “Hard Headed Woman,” as well as song tributes to Bob Dylan, Woody Guthrie and Waylon Jennings.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Anthony Vazquez/Sun-Times</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>Featuring a handful of brazen originals from her twice-Grammy nominated 2025 album as well as song tributes to fellow folk and country insurgents Bob Dylan, Woody Guthrie and Waylon Jennings, the set list was carefully plotted as a celebration of outlaw music. </p><p>It’s a badge Price continues to proudly wear even as she’s policed by Nashville ilk that have branded her a rabble-rouser outsider.</p><p>“I’ve lived there long enough that I’ve earned the right to hate it,” Price said, not shy about her sentiments regarding the country music capital. Still, Price (who was born and raised in Aledo in western Illinois) creates a sound that fits in with the best of Nashville, past and present. Whether it’s a barn raiser like “Red Eye Flight,” the rockabilly twang beauty of “Wild At Heart,” the acoustic slide lullaby “Close To You” or the sassy “Don’t Wake Me Up,” a song written in her childhood bedroom a few Christmases ago, Price’s material has a retro-country seal that has throughlines to Patsy Cline, Loretta Lynn, Emmylou Harris and Dolly Parton.</p><div class="Enhancement" class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Margo Price performs Saturday at Metro in Wrigleyville.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Anthony Vazquez/Sun-Times</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>The visuals furthered the Music City vibe, like the cowboy hats that appeared in the crowd and onstage or Price’s ensemble of knee-high suede boots that stomped the floor and long fringe cuff bracelets that swayed furiously as she strummed her guitar or slapped her tambourine. Or, the cowhide rugs, salt lamps and mushroom stools on the stage that made Metro feel like an intimate back-of-the-bar listening room, especially when coupled with an exceptional band that commanded attention.</p><p>Alec Newman’s tender and steady bass, Brandon Combs’ controlled drum beats and Sean Thompson’s incredible wielding of electric guitar that often veered off into “Freebird”-level solos were incredible accompaniments to the night’s soundscape. Price’s chemistry with guitarist Logan Ledger (who also opened the show with his solo material) was palpable as they beautifully dueted on “Close To You” and “Love Me Like You Used To,” with Ledger perfectly taking over the reins for Tyler Childers, who appears on the recorded collab track. Ledger also had a moment in the main set to wow the crowd with his original tune, “All The Wine In California” as Price took a reprieve to head backstage to change into a silver sequined dress for the encore.</p><div class="RelatedList Enhancement" data-module data-align-center> <div class="RelatedList-title">Related</div> <ul class="RelatedList-items"> <li class="RelatedList-items-item"> <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/music/2025/09/04/margo-price-evanston-folk-festival-headliner" >Country singer-songwriter Margo Price’s heart remains firmly planted in Illinois: ‘The Midwest will always be my home’</a> </li> <li class="RelatedList-items-item"> <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/music/2024/12/04/mavis-staples-says-i-dont-ever-want-to-stop-singing-as-stars-gather-to-perform-at-85th-birthday-celebration" >Mavis Staples says ‘I don’t ever want to stop singing’ as stars gather to perform at 85th birthday celebration</a> </li> </ul> </div> <p>“Both these guys on either side of me have records downstairs,” Price said, promoting the great talents of Thompson and Ledger, knowing full well she wasn’t the only star of the night. The merch booth also had a spotlight on Farm Aid — as Price shared, with any donation, fans were able to enter to win one of her signed signature guitars. “We need to support our local farmers!” Price demanded. A few steps after she performed the Spanish folk song “De Colores,” an anthem linked to the United Farm Workers.</p><p>Of all the standout moments of the night, the one that stuck after the show ended was her rollicking single “Don’t Let the Bastards Get You Down,” that called for resiliency and to keep up the fight in the face of adversity. It’s songs like these that have netted Price co-signs from her heroes and generational game changers like Joan Baez, Kris Kristofferson and fellow Illinoisan Mavis Staples with whom Price worked on the 2022 song “Fight to Make It,” with proceeds going to reproductive justice organizations.</p><p>Price’s material hearkens back to the very foundation of country music that was used as protest — and “outlaw” or not, she dares to press the community on what the America they sing about really stands for. As she ended the night throwing roses out to the crowd, you can only hope she saved one for herself.</p><p><b></b></p><h3>Margo Price set list for Feb. 28 concert at Metro in Chicago</h3><p>About To Find Out<br>Wild At Heart<br>Red Eye Flight<br>Don’t Wake Me Up<br>Close To You<br>Love Me Like You Used To Do<br>I Just Don’t Give A Damn (George Jones cover)<br>Tennessee Song<br>Keep A Picture<br>Prelude (Hard Headed Woman)<br>Don't Let the Bastards Get You Down<br>Oval Room (Blaze Foley cover)<br>De Colores (traditional cover)<br>Deportee (Plane Wreck at Los Gatos) (Woody Guthrie cover)<br>All The Wine In California (Logan Ledger cover)<br>Kissing You Goodbye (Waylon Jennings cover)<br>Hurtin’ (on the Bottle)<br>Maggie’s Farm (Bob Dylan cover)</p>
entries.author: Selena Fragassi

entries.title: Cook County Circuit Court warns about scam seeking unpaid parking charges
entries.summary: <p>The Cook County Circuit Court is warning residents about a scam “hearing notice” soliciting payments for fake parking charges.</p><p>The notice, titled “Illinois Circuit Court – Hearing Notice,” falsely claims the receiver needs to pay for unpaid parking charges or face court action, according to the office of Chief Judge Charles Beach.</p><p>The scam includes a QR code and directs the receiver to scan it and pay the fine. The Circuit Court does not send hearing notices in this format, it does not demand payments through a QR code, and it does not threaten arrest or credit reporting for unpaid parking tickets, according to the warning.</p><p>If anyone encounters this scam, the chief judge encourages the notice be sent to local law enforcement and the Illinois attorney general’s office.</p>
entries.author: Sun-Times Wire

entries.title: Pete Crow-Armstrong, Alex Bregman, Matthew Boyd leaving Cubs camp for World Baseball Classic
entries.summary: <p>MESA, Ariz. — Pete Crow-Armstrong admitted he will miss his Cubs teammates for maybe as long as three weeks.</p><p>“But this is special,” Crow-Armstrong said as he, third baseman Alex Bregman and pitcher Matthew Boyd will leave spring training to play for Team USA in the World Baseball Classic.</p><p>“This is obviously something new for me, and I just feel very lucky that I get to experience something like this. I'm ready to play some real meaningful baseball and just go wear those colors. I haven't done it for some years, and getting to do it at the highest stage is going to be special.”</p><p>Crow-Armstrong and Bregman each collected two hits Sunday against the White Sox, with Bregman planning to host a few of his Team USA teammates at his house.</p><p>Bregman hasn’t lost in international competition while playing for Team USA four times at the college level and in the 2017 WBC, and he relishes the bond with his teammates for short periods.</p><p>“I don’t know what is about it, it’s probably the stars and stripes, to be honest,” Bregman said. “You become a family and a team really quickly. Even though we’re in different camps now, we’ll be in the same clubhouse (Monday).</p><p>“The coolest part about it is the bond that’s created right away when you step in that locker room when you know what you’re representing and playing for.”</p><p>Bregman’s first three weeks with the Cubs has been smooth.</p><p>“I feel like our team's in a really good place right now,” Bregman said. “Guys are focused and locked in, ready for the season, getting preparing every day. I think it's a great group. And I'm very excited.”</p><p>Team USA opens pool play Friday against Brazil in Houston. Among the other prominent Cubs players participating in the WBC are pitcher Jameson Taillon (Canada), outfielder Seiya Suzuki (Japan), pitcher Javier Asaad (Mexico), catchers Miguel Amaya and Christian Bethancourt (Panama) and closer Daniel Palencia (Venezuela).</p><h3>Outfield auditions</h3><p>The departures of Crow-Armstrong and Suzuki create more opportunities for Michael Conforto, Dylan Carlson, Chas McCormick and Kevin Alcantara for a backup spot in the outfield.</p><p>“That’s probably where we benefit from it,” Counsell said “The other side of is, you'd love to have your guys around.”</p><p>Counsell confirmed that Alcantara, who played his first game Saturday as the designated hitter after recovering from hernia surgery, will make his first start in the outfield Monday.</p><h3>Shaw salad</h3><p>The glut of backup outfield auditions could cut into playing time for infielder Matt Shaw and his utility role.</p><p>“I’d love for him to have 50 games out there, but that’s not realistic,” Counsell said. “Eight-ish games? That’s where we’re at.”</p><h3>Ben is back</h3><p>Infielder Ben Cowles was claimed off waivers by the Blue Jays. To make room for Cowles on the 40-man roster, pitcher Shelby Miller was placed on the 60-day injured list.</p><p>This marks the third time Cowles has joined the Cubs. Cowles was waived by the Cubs after Miller was signed on Feb. 15.</p><h3>White Sox 5, Cubs 1</h3><p>Left-hander Shota Imanaga was tagged for three solo home runs in 2 2/3 innings. One encouraging aspect was that Imanaga’s fastball topped out at 95 mph, but his bigger concern is that he will be able to sustain that velocity as he pitches deeper into games. Sox top outfield prospect Braden Montgomery tagged an 82 mph slider by Imanaga for a solo homer in the second.</p><p>• Poor fundamentals gnawed at manager Craig Counsell in 2024, but he can be assured that the rundown drills performed this spring have carried out to exhibition games. Shortstop Dansby Swanson fielded Tanner Murray’s grounder and threw quickly to home plate, where catcher Carson Kelly chased Edgar Quero to third before Alex Bregman tagged him in the fifth.</p><p>• Pete Crow-Armstrong batted only .188 against left-handers last season, but he did an exceptional job of slapping a slider from Sox left-hander Anthony Kay into left field for a single in the second.</p><p>• On deck: Cubs at Reds, 2:05 p.m. Monday, Goodyear, Marquee, Jameson Taillon vs. Brady Singer.</p>
entries.author: Mark Gonzales

entries.title: What is Pulaski Day? Here's what's closed and the history of this Chicago holiday
entries.summary: <p>Pulaski Day is celebrated in Chicago and Cook County on the first Monday of March. The day honors a Revolutionary War hero and the city’s vibrant Polish American community. Here’s what to know about the holiday, its history and how it will be celebrated this year.</p><h3>What’s closed for Pulaski Day?</h3><p>All Chicago and Cook County government offices and courts will be closed on Monday, March 2. Chicago Public Library locations will also be closed all day.</p><p>Most schools, including Chicago Public Schools, will be open.</p><p>Post offices and banks will also be open, as it is not a federal holiday.</p><h3>Who was Casimir Pulaski?</h3><p>Casimir Pulaski was a Polish military leader who fought against Russian control in Poland before joining the American Revolution. After meeting Benjamin Franklin in Paris, Pulaski traveled to America in 1777 and quickly became a key figure in the American Revolutionary War, according to the Chicago Public Library.</p><p>Pulaski organized and led the country’s first cavalry, earning him the title “Father of the American Cavalry,” according to the National Park Service. Pulaski died in 1779 from injuries during the Battle of Savannah.</p><p>His name is now a familiar sight in Chicago — seen on Pulaski Road, Pulaski Park and other landmarks.</p><h3>What is Pulaski Day?</h3><p>Pulaski Day, observed on the first Monday of March, honors Pulaski’s role in the American Revolution and celebrates the contributions of Chicago’s Polish American community. The holiday is held around Pulaski’s birthday, March 6.</p><p>Illinois established the holiday in 1977 under Gov. James Thompson. In 1986, the Chicago City Council passed a resolution introduced by Mayor Harold Washington to officially recognize it, following strong advocacy from local Polish organizations and community leaders.</p><p>Chicago’s Polish population — one of the largest outside of Poland — has long used Pulaski Day to celebrate Pulaski’s legacy and its cultural heritage. As of 2023, about 130,000 Chicago residents and more than 720,000 people in the Chicago metro area have Polish ancestry, according to the Census Bureau.</p><p>Illinois is the only state with an official Pulaski Day. However, New York City and Buffalo, New York, which have significant Polish communities, mark Pulaski’s contributions with parades held at different times of the year.</p><p>Pulaski Day was initially observed with school closures across Illinois, but that changed beginning in the early 2000s.</p><h3>How is Pulaski celebrated?</h3><p>Chicago’s celebrations center on an annual event at the Polish Museum of America. </p><p>"Pulaski has been memorialized in the U.S. for generations," Richard Owsiany, president of the Polish Museum of America, said last year. "For almost 30 years, the museum has hosted this event to honor what he did for the country and to keep his legacy alive."</p><p>This year's event will include remarks from Chicago Mayor Brandon Johnson, Illinois State Treasurer Michael Frerichs, Cook County Treasurer Maria Pappas and others. It will also feature live artistic performances, filmed presentations and the traditional wreath-laying ceremony at Stanislaw Batowski’s painting of "Pulaski at Savannah." The public can view the event at 10 a.m. Monday at <a class="Link" href="http://www.PolishMuseumOfAmerica.org" target="_blank" >PolishMuseumOfAmerica.org</a>.</p><h3>What does Pulaski Day mean for the Polish community in Chicago?</h3><p>For many in Chicago’s Polish community, Pulaski Day is about more than remembering a historic figure — it’s a chance to celebrate the heritage and come together.</p><p>“Pulaski came to the U.S. to fight for your freedom and ours,” Bogdan Pukszta, executive director of the Polish American Chamber of Commerce, said in an interview before the holiday in 2025. “For Poles like me, who were born in Poland, Pulaski is someone we grew up learning about. Here, it’s about sharing that legacy with the broader American community.”</p><p>Pukszta moved to Chicago in the early 1980s, just before Illinois recognized the holiday.</p><p>“When Pulaski Day was first established, all schools had the day off. That’s changed, but the meaning hasn’t,” he said. “It’s an opportunity for us to celebrate, reflect and catch up with the community.”</p><p>Events like Pulaski Day also help younger generations stay connected to their roots, Pukszta said.</p><p>“For those familiar with Poland, Pulaski is a hero. For Americans, he should be remembered as someone who fought for this country’s freedom,” he said. “This holiday bridges both identities.”</p><p>Chicago’s Polish community gathers for other key events like the May 3 Constitution Day Parade and Polish Independence Day in November — but Pulaski Day holds a unique place as a symbol of shared history between Poland and the U.S.</p><p>“It’s not just about Polish pride,” Pukszta said. “It’s about honoring someone who fought for both nations and recognizing the contributions of Polish Americans to Illinois.”</p>
entries.author: Rafaela Jinich

entries.title: Swimmers jump in frigid Lake Michigan for annual Polar Plunge
entries.summary: <p>With air temperatures hovering below freezing Sunday morning, thousands of Chicagoans decided it was a great day for a swim.</p><p>About 4,300 swimmers gathered at North Avenue Beach for the 26th annual Polar Plunge, put on by Special Children's Charities. Each year, participants raise money for Special Olympics Illinios, and this year's group has garnered more than $1.5 million in donations, falling short of the $2 million goal and down from last year's total of $1.7 million, according to the event's website.</p><p>Swimmers — some in swimsuits, others in full costume — ran into the lake and dunked, shrieked and gasped from the cold. The lake temperature was 35 degrees as swimmers jumped in. Crayons, Santa Claus and hot dogs were among the costumes participants donned.</p><p>Mayor Brandon Johnson participated <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/news/2024/03/03/thousands-splash-lake-michigan-special-olympics-polar-plunge-north-avenue-beach-charity" >two years ago</a>, when the event set a record with more than 5,000 attendees taking the dip in unseasonably warm weather and donations totaled of $1.9 million.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item"> <bsp-carousel entries.title: Cubs lefty Justin Steele still months from return, despite progess in rehab
entries.summary: <p>MESA, Ariz. — Justin Steele’s giddiness after being cleared to expand his repertoire of pitches and increase the intensity of his rehabilitation overshadowed a long-range goal the Cubs know too well.</p><p>“I would still be sticking to the same timeline that we kind of been saying, May-June,” Steele said Sunday, nearly 10 months since undergoing surgery to repair a torn ulnar collateral ligament and flexor tendon tear in his left arm.</p><p>“And all of this is with the thought in mind that the outings in October and November are going to be the ones that matter the most. So I would say, keep that in mind as we're talking and thinking about this.”</p><p>Steele’s injury was the first of several injuries that eventually caught up to the Cubs and cost them a chance at advancing to the National League Championship Series.</p><p>Fellow left-hander Shota Imanaga faded late, and rookie sensation Cade Horton suffered a right rib fracture shortly before the end of the regular season.</p><p>The Cubs settled for Mike Soroka instead of ponying up for Shane Bieber at the trade deadline, and Soroka went on the injured list and missed six weeks because of a shoulder strain while Bieber posted a 4-2 record after his trade from the Guardians to the Blue Jays, who won Game 4 of the World Series with Bieber limited the World Champion Dodgers to four hits in 5 1/3 innings.</p><p>The Cubs fortified their rotation this winter with the acquisition of Edward Cabrera that cost them top outfield prospect Owen Caissie, and the anticipated return of Steele — who posted a 3.10 ERA in 78 starts from 2022-24 — could bring more than the equivalent of a mid-season trade.</p><p>Manager Craig Counsell remains cautiously optimistic about Steele’s progress and his long-range view.</p><p>“We’re on the same page, and we’ll keep communicating,” Counsell said. “As you’re going through (rehab), you never want to slow down. You want to earn very step and make progress. And I think that’s a very important part.</p><p>“Let me throw some other things in the equation. We got to kind of balance that all out, but I think we'll come up with something good, and I think the timing of this is going to be really good.”</p><p>After receiving clearance from Dr. Keith Meister (as part of his Arizona visit to check on the progress of his patients), Steele will be allowed to incorporate breaking pitches into his pitch mix as he increases the intensity of his rehab from 35-40 pitches to eventually facing batters.</p><p>The Cubs are stretching out Colin Rea and Javier Asaad to serve as insurance in the event projected starters Jameson Tallion, Matthew Boyd, Imanaga, Cabrera and Horton aren’t available by the end of March.</p><p>Rea made 27 starts last season, and Asaad could start a game for Team Mexico in the World Baseball Classic.</p><p>Counsell anticipates Rea will start “a lot of games this year,” and his ability to shift between the rotation and bullpen is “what makes seasons and make the stability of that is what makes seasons go well and go smoothly and helps those around you.”</p><p>Steele, meanwhile, is eager to celebrate any milestone such as getting clearance from Meister while feeling no urge to rush with rotation depth he described as “amazing.”</p><p>“It's really important that I'm hitting my stride at that point. That's when it’s going to help the team the most.”<br></p>
entries.author: Mark Gonzales
